Your Sunday Opera
Like opera? Wish you could hear
more of it? You can over WFIU, for
your University station broadcasts a
complete opera every Sunday from
2:00 to 4:30 P.M. Operas range from
the familiar to those rarely heard much
less performed.
During the first months of this new
season, Your Sunday Opera will broad¬
cast a number of well-known operas.
If you’re a follower of the Metropolitan
Opera broadcasts, you’ll have an op¬
portunity to hear many of those same
operas on WFIU during the coming
months. Operas scheduled are:
September
6 Spontini, La Vest ale
13 Wagner, Tristan und Isolde
20 Puccini, Tosca
27 Verdi, Simon Boccanegra
October
4 Debussy, Pelleas et Melisande
11 Mozart, The Marriage of Figaro
18 Strauss, Der Rosenkavalier
25 Verdi, Rigoletto
Treasury of Music
Treasury of Music is designed to pre¬
sent compositions that for some reason
or other are not usually broadcast.
You’ll hear choral works and others of
unusual length on this series, besides
interesting groups of works.
Currently, T reasury of Music is
heard Saturday afternoons from 3:00
to 4:30. There will be no broadcast
on Sept. 26, and starting Oct. 10,
Treasury will be aired Saturday eve¬
nings starting at 7:30. During the
coming months, you’ll hear:
September
5 Schutz, St. Matthew Passion
12 Vivaldi, Conflict Between Harmony
and Invention
19 Haydn, Saint Cecilia Mass
October
3 Hindemith, Marienleben
10 Vivaldi, The Seasons; Glazaounov, The
Seasons
17 Bizet—Orchestral Works
24 Renaissance Choral Music
31 Beethoven, Symphony No. 6, “Pas¬
toral”; Vaughan Williams, A Pastoral
Symphony
